data.title: Digital 2024: Global Overview Report ‚Äî DataReportal ‚Äì Global Digital Insights
data.meta_description: Everything you need to know about digital and social media use around the world in 2024. 560+ pages of data, trends, and insights - all free.
data.text:
Connected time creeps back up

This time last year, one of our top stories was that people were spending less time using the internet.

At the time, average daily internet use had declined by 5 percent year on year, and we wondered whether this might signal a fundamental change in how people use connected tech.

However, our latest data reveals that this trend has actually reversed.

Let‚Äôs start by exploring overall internet time.

The time we spend online

Ongoing research from GWI shows that the typical internet user now spends 6 hours and 40 minutes online each day.

That‚Äôs up by almost 1 percent compared with this time last year, when internet users reported spending an average of 6 hours and 36 minutes per day using connected tech [note: time values on the chart have been rounded from more granular data, so while the difference looks like 4 minutes, it‚Äôs actually closer to 3 minutes].

It‚Äôs important to highlight that revisions to GWI‚Äôs methodology over the past year may have affected this change figure, but the fact that these values have remained relatively stable over the past five quarters suggests that this change figure is still representative.

Time online by country

At the upper end of the scale, South Africans still spend the greatest amount of time online, with the typical user in the country reporting that they spend an average of 9 hours and 24 minutes per day using the internet.

If we assume that the average person spends between 7 and 8 hours per day sleeping, that figure suggests that the internet now accounts for close to 60 percent of waking hours amongst South Africa‚Äôs connected population.

For perspective, internet adoption in South Africa currently stands at close to 75 percent.

Brazilians rank second by daily online time, with the country‚Äôs netizens spending an average of 9 hours and 13 minutes per day using the internet.

And Filipinos close out the top 3, with the typical user in the South-East Asian archipelago spending 8 hours and 52 minutes per day online.

However, it‚Äôs a very different story at the other end of the spectrum.

Japanese people say they spend an average of less than 4 hours per day using the internet, which is over an hour a day less than any other nation in GWI‚Äôs survey.

Meanwhile, Denmark sits second-to-bottom, with Danes saying they‚Äôre online for an average of just 5 hours and 8 minutes per day.

And South Koreans rank third-last, with users spending an average of 5 hours and 19 minutes per day using the internet.

Generational differences

However, there are some subtle differences in these rankings when we cut the data by age.

For example, younger people are more likely to use online music platforms than they are to use maps and location-based services.

On the flip-side, music platforms only rank ninth for users aged 55 to 64.

Meanwhile, older generations are more likely to use email compared with today‚Äôs youth, but it‚Äôs worth pointing out that almost half of all internet users aged 16 to 24 still say that they use email on a monthly basis.

But perhaps the most noteworthy difference across the ages is that younger people are actually more likely to use social networks than they are to use chat and messaging apps.

This order is reversed across all other age groups in GWI‚Äôs latest survey results, and I confess I was surprised to see social networks at the top of this younger cohort‚Äôs activities.

As we saw in the overall data though, the difference between the two is only very slight, and the key takeaway here is that both activities are hugely popular across all ages.

Is internet use becoming less ‚Äúpurposeful‚Äù?

But this brings us neatly back to another of the trends that I highlighted in my 2023 analysis.

When trying to make sense of the decline in online time that we‚Äôd seen towards the end of last year, one of the hypotheses I explored with GWI‚Äôs Trends team was that people might have been becoming more ‚Äúpurposeful‚Äù and ‚Äúconsidered‚Äù in their online activities.

As GWI posited in their own analysis of the data:

‚ÄúThere are only so many hours in the day, and people want to know their online time isn‚Äôt being wasted.‚Äù

I still believe that‚Äôs a solid conclusion, but if this was indeed the primary motivation for that erstwhile change in our online behaviour, we might conclude that people have been happy to waste a bit more time online over the past year.

But then again, a less cynical perspective might be that people tried to achieve more online during 2023.

Either way, GWI‚Äôs data reveals that the average number of reasons for going online has crept back up again over the past year, from a low of 7.04 in Q3 2022, to 7.22 in the most recent round of data (Q3 2023).

[Side note: this average is largely determined by the options that people can select from in GWI‚Äôs survey. In the chart below, respondents could choose from the same 19 options in each survey ‚Äúwave‚Äù, so the variation in the average represents a like-for-like comparison over time.]

Next up, if we focus solely on users over the age of 18, Instagram‚Äôs reported ad reach in the United States still exceeds that of TikTok (162 million vs. 148 million, respectively).

And we see a similar story across Western and Northern Europe, with Instagram‚Äôs combined adult ad reach across the region (126 million) considerably ahead of TikTok‚Äôs reported total (100 million).

However, data suggests that TikTok‚Äôs adult audience is significantly larger than Instagram‚Äôs in other parts of the world.

For example, across Western Asia, TikTok reports adult ad reach of 149 million, which is more than 20 percent higher than the 122 million for the same cohort reported by Instagram.

Similarly, TikTok‚Äôs reported adult ad reach across the African continent is 72 percent higher than Instagram‚Äôs (144 million vs. 84 million, respectively).

And finally, TikTok reports adult ad reach of 345 million users across South-Eastern Asia, whereas Instagram only reports reach of 154 million for the same age group across the region.

So ‚Äì as is so often the case ‚Äì different platforms may offer different benefits and advantages, depending on what the marketer is trying to achieve.

Even more options

For me, the most important takeaway from all of this data is that marketers now have even more compelling options to choose from.

And what‚Äôs more, the data shows that both platforms continue to grow at impressive rates.

The Instagram reach figures reported in Meta‚Äôs resources suggest that the platform‚Äôs global reach has increased by 334 million over the past year, resulting in year-on-year growth of 25.3 percent.

Third-party perspective

First up, our analysis of mobile app intelligence from data.ai tells quite a different story to the companies‚Äô ad reach figures, although there are some important similarities too.

By the end of Q3 2023, data.ai reports that TikTok‚Äôs active user base was already larger than Instagram‚Äôs across key Northern American markets, albeit only by a very small margin.

TikTok was also significantly ahead of Instagram across top economies in South-Eastern Asia.

However, Instagram still led TikTok by a considerable margin across larger economies in Europe, and it was also well ahead across primary markets in Southern America.

Overall, data.ai‚Äôs figures suggest that Instagram still leads TikTok, but reduced data availability for lower- and middle-income countries likely skews this finding in Instagram‚Äôs favour.

However, another key takeaway from data.ai‚Äôs intelligence is that both these platforms have each added more active users than any of the other top social platforms over the past few months.

And data.ai‚Äôs nuanced usage data provides even more valuable perspectives.

Comparing time and frequency

The company‚Äôs analysis shows that TikTok had the highest average time per user of any of the top ‚Äúsocial‚Äù apps between July and September 2023, with the platform‚Äôs typical Android user clocking in at 34 hours per month.

In other words, at a worldwide level, the typical TikTok user now spends an average of more than an hour per day using the platform.

That‚Äôs almost 6 hours per month ahead of second-placed YouTube, which sees an average of slightly over 28 hours per month, per user for its Android app.

That growth figure might seem quite small in comparison to the ones that we reported above for Instagram and TikTok, but it‚Äôs important to remember that the vast majority of China‚Äôs internet users already use Weixin.

Data from CNNIC (in Mandarin) shows that more than 97 percent of the country‚Äôs connected population uses instant messaging, and while there are other messaging options in China, Weixin is by far the most popular choice.

However, therein lies the importance of the distinction between WeChat and Weixin.

While Tencent groups the two apps together in its reporting, the apps offer quite different benefits.

Weixin is closely integrated into almost every aspect of everyday life in China ‚Äì both online and offline ‚Äì to the extent that foreign visitors can often find it difficult to pay for things or get around without it.

However, without the benefits of these ‚Äúnetwork effects‚Äù, WeChat has struggled to gain the same level of momentum outside of its domestic market.

Indeed, the latest data from GWI suggests that more than 87 percent of the world‚Äôs WeChat users are located in China, and less than 5 percent of the working-age internet population outside of the country says that they use WeChat in any given month.

But despite these challenges, WeChat continues to grow, and even if its success remains limited to China, at least that success is concentrated in the world‚Äôs largest connected market.

The wonderful world of TikTok hashtags

One of the most fascinating ‚Äì and perhaps perplexing ‚Äì datasets in this year‚Äôs report relates to TikTok hashtags.

Just before we dive into the data, it‚Äôs important to highlight that there‚Äôs no ‚Äúofficial‚Äù list of the platform‚Äôs top tags, nor is there any easy way to identify which ones garner the most attention.

As a result, this research required an incredibly laborious, manual trawl, and there‚Äôs every chance that we‚Äôve missed one or two hashtags that should have featured in this ranking (side note: if you know of one that‚Äôs missing, please let me know).

Caveats aside though, this data offers a real treasure trove of insight and inspiration for cultural observers and marketers alike.

It‚Äôs all for you

First up, the obvious winner: #fyp.

This initialism of ‚Äúfor your page‚Äù has long been the most popular hashtag on the platform, and is still used by TikTokers everywhere in the hopes of getting their clips featured in the platform‚Äôs main feed.

And this ubiquity has resulted in some truly staggering results.

Data published on the platform itself suggests that TikToks tagged with #fyp have amassed a total of 55¬Ω trillion views.

Yes, you read that correctly: trillion.

For perspective, even if each of those views only lasted for one second, the combined total would equate to 1.76 million years.

But #fyp isn‚Äôt the only hashtag delivering eye-watering view counts.

Moreover, none of the TikTok hashtag guides that we read across the internet whilst preparing this research even mention this tendency to polyglotism.

So, let‚Äôs take a closer look at which non-English tags have gained the most momentum on TikTok so far.

‚Ä¶but it‚Äôs still (almost) all for you

First up, the Spanish-language equivalent of ‚Äúfor you‚Äù ‚Äì #parati ‚Äì is the most widely used non-English hashtag on TikTok today, garnering a hefty combined view count of 8.43 trillion.

[Side note for the pedants: it could be argued that the use of the Japanese katakana character, ‚Äú„ÉÑ‚Äù ‚Äì pronounced ‚Äútsu‚Äù ‚Äì in #fyp„ÉÑ qualifies that hashtag as the top ‚Äúnon-English‚Äù entry, but this character‚Äôs popularity stems from its resemblance to a smiling face, and there‚Äôs no obvious use of the Japanese language in this particular instance, so I decided to ignore it].

Next up is #xuhuong, which likely relates to the Vietnamese words ‚Äúxu h∆∞·ªõng‚Äù, meaning ‚Äútrend‚Äù (note that #trending and #trend both appear as English tags within the top 40 as well).

For context, TikTok reports close to 68 million users in Vietnam, making it the platform‚Äôs fifth-largest country audience.

#Xuhuong is particularly popular amongst users in South-East Asia, and posts featuring this tag have amassed an impressive 2.57 trillion combined views.

However, our analysis shows that use of the #xuhuong tag isn‚Äôt limited to Vietnamese users.

The third-most popular non-English tag on TikTok is the Arabic #ÿßŸÉÿ≥ÿ®ŸÑŸàÿ±.

However, this tag is an interesting one, because it‚Äôs a phonetic transliteration of the word ‚Äúexplore‚Äù in English, and isn‚Äôt actually a ‚Äústandard‚Äù Arabic word.

It‚Äôs also worth highlighting that this Arabic rendering of ‚Äúexplore‚Äù has had more success than the English-language #explore has, with the Arabic version attracting almost a trillion more views.

And for added context, it‚Äôs worth noting that #ÿßŸÉÿ≥ÿ®ŸÑŸàÿ± has also gained meaningful momentum on Instagram, where it has been used in more than 125 million posts.

Next up in our TikTok tag ranking is the Cyrillic #—Ä–µ–∫–æ–º–µ–Ω–¥–∞—Ü–∏–∏, closely followed by its derivative form, #—Ä–µ–∫.

The longer tag is the Russian word for ‚Äúrecommendation‚Äù, and posts with this tag had attracted 2.24 trillion views by the time we compiled this list.

And for added perspective, TikTok‚Äôs latest data indicate that the platform has 58.6 million users in Russia, placing it sixth in our TikTok country ranking.

#–†–µ–∫ literally translates to ‚Äúrivers‚Äù in English, but in this case, TikTok users are likely using it as an abbreviation of ‚Äú—Ä–µ–∫–æ–º–µ–Ω–¥–∞—Ü–∏–∏‚Äù.

However, use of this particular abbreviation may also reflect a subtle nod to the ‚Äúflow‚Äù ‚Äì or ‚Äúfeed‚Äù ‚Äì of content on TikTok‚Äôs ‚ÄúFor You Page‚Äù [I may be reading far too much into that of course, but the nerd in me can‚Äôt resist].

Next in our ranking of the most popular non-English tags is #pourtoi, which is the French-language equivalent of ‚Äúfor you‚Äù, while #comedia ‚Äì the Spanish-language word for ‚Äúcomedy‚Äù ‚Äì rounds out this list of non-english tags.

But there are still a few more tags in the top 40 that are worthy of our attention.

Make me famous

For the uninitiated, one of the most confusing tags in this list might be #xyzbca.

With a total of 4.23 trillion combined views, the tag has clearly been used a huge number of times, but the characters themselves don‚Äôt actually have any meaning.

Analysing the potential origins of this tag is probably a bit cringe ‚Äì it‚Äôs quite probably entirely random ‚Äì but for a Gen Xer like me, it‚Äôs vaguely reminiscent of cheat codes from old video games.

But if that sounds like a stretch, remember why people are using these tags: to ‚Äúgo viral‚Äù.

And if me writing ‚Äúgo viral‚Äù also sounds cringe, take a look at tags 3, 14, and 15 in our top 40 list.

Oh, and #goviral has also amassed more than 880 billion views, so ‚Äì while it doesn‚Äôt quite qualify for the top 40 ‚Äì it‚Äôs not far off it.

Moreover, the likelihood of ‚Äúgoing viral‚Äù on TikTok today is somewhat akin to winning the lottery, so perhaps a ‚Äúcheat code‚Äù isn‚Äôt a bad analogy.

However, the standout entry for me in this ranking of top TikTok tags is #fyppppppppppppppppppppppp.

No, I didn‚Äôt fall asleep with my finger on the keyboard; that hashtag really is ‚Äúfy‚Äù followed by 23 Ps, and yes, it really has attracted more than 958 billion views.

But why 23 Ps and not 22 or 24, you ask?

Beats me.

If you know, I‚Äôd genuinely love to know the answer. Drop me a note.

Wrapping up

That‚Äôs almost all for this year‚Äôs analysis ‚Äì thanks for making it through 10,000+ words so far! ‚Äì but you might like to know that we‚Äôll start publishing our Digital 2024 local country reports towards the end of February.

We‚Äôll share those as soon as they‚Äôre ready, but if you‚Äôre worried you might have missed something, head over to our complete Global Digital Reports library, where you‚Äôll be able to find everything you need.

And just in case you want even more analysis, be sure to check out our complete collection of Digital 2024 Deep Dive articles ‚Äì you can find all of those here.

But just before you go‚Ä¶

And finally‚Ä¶

We spent a lot of time earlier in this analysis exploring the ongoing battle for supremacy between Instagram and TikTok.

However, a far more storied battle has been taking place across the internet over the past 12 months.

Unlike that social media story though, this battle has a clear winner‚Ä¶ at least for this year.

When it comes to digital today, it‚Äôs all about the dogs.

Some people may tell you that the internet was invented for cats, but ‚Äì even if that assertion might have held water back in the 90s ‚Äì canines are well and truly top dog as we enter 2024.

Even a cursory glance at Google search results will tell you that dogs are ahead, with the world‚Äôs top search engine returning close to 10 billion pages for ‚Äúdog‚Äù, compared with just 8 billion for ‚Äúcat‚Äù.

You might pawsit that cats could simply do with better SEO, but it turns out that ranking on the first page of Google probably isn‚Äôt felines‚Äô top frustration.

Indeed, our careful analysis of data published by Google Trends reveals that today‚Äôs internet users are 80 percent more likely to search for Dogs than they are to search for Cats.

And yes, for the G-Trends nerds out there, we used broad search terms for this analysis rather than specific keywords, and we also took a worldwide view across the past 12 months as our base.

Cats appear to have the upper hand paw when it comes to Wikipedia though, and the number of people visiting the main page for Cats outnumbers those visiting the main Dog page by a ratio of more than two to one.

It appears as though supporters of Felis catus have been hard at work too, with the genus‚Äôs Wikipedia page now available in 262 languages, compared with Canis lupus familiaris‚Äôs 260.

Editors have also made significantly more lifetime edits to the Cat Wikipedia page, outnumbering edits to the Dog page by 15,170 to 12,535.

Perhaps surprisingly though, the Dog page appeared on Wikipedia before the Cat page did ‚Äì by a whole 34 days.

However, Wikipedia was the only triumph for cats in 2023, and when it comes to social media, dogs win ‚Äì hands paws down.

For context, Instagram users have published almost 376 million posts to the platform tagged with #dog, compared with just 290 million tagged with #cat.

And the #DogsOfTikTok are winning too.

TikToks tagged with #dog have garnered a massive 575 billion views, compared with 502 billion for TikToks tagged with #cat.

And just as an aside, this data reveals that the world has collectively viewed posts tagged with either #dog or #cat more than 1 trillion times.

Yes, you read that right: it‚Äôs ‚Äôrillion, with a ‚ÄúT‚Äù.

Meanwhile, the dogs are even winning on X.

We‚Äôre fully expecting raucous claims of bot activity and accusations of political bias here, but the numbers don‚Äôt lie: the platform-formerly-known-as-Twitter‚Äôs own advertising resources reveal that a hefty 291.6 million X users are ‚Äúinterested in‚Äù dogs, compared with a meagre 49.2 million users who are ‚Äúinterested in‚Äù cats.

So, what‚Äôs the overall conclusion here?

Well, if you represent #TeamDog, it‚Äôs perhaps time to freshen up that Wikipedia page, and convert your social media presence into tangible traffic and results.

However, if you‚Äôre on the side of #TeamCat‚Ä¶ well, it may be time for a new agency. If you need any ideas, I have the purrfect suggestion.

That‚Äôs all from me for this year‚Äôs flagship analysis, but I‚Äôll be back on your screens in just a few short weeks to bring you the first of our Digital 2024 Quarterly Statshot Reports.

Until then, #BeMoreDog üê∂

Disclosure: Simon Kemp is a brand ambassador for both GWI and data.ai.
